Title.evidence: This study was a randomized controlled trial

Trial_Design.evidence: This study was a randomized controlled trial with two parallel, separately analyzed cohorts

Participants.evidence: children undergoing in‐office cast removal or in-office percutaneous pin removal at a single urban tertiary institution

Intervention.evidence: VR gaming simulation (n = 37), VR goggles with a noninteractive video (n = 36), or a tablet computer with the same noninteractive video (n = 40)

Objective.evidence: Is a VR gaming simulation more effective than either of two forms of noninteractive visual distraction

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes included preprocedure-to–maximum heart rate increase (objective measure) and preprocedure and postprocedure pain and anxiety using a VAS (subjective measures)

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: were enrolled and randomized into one of three groups

Number_Randomised.evidence: In all, 235 patients were enrolled in the study

Number_Analysed.evidence: 210 patients (mean ± SD age 9 ± 3 years; 48% [100] girls) were included in the final analyses

Result_Outcome.evidence: largest mean difference -6 bpm [95% CI -16 to 3]; p = 0.36
